I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the annual country programming mission in December 2011, the Government of 
the People’s Republic of China (PRC) asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide 
policy  and  advisory  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  a  study  to  support  highway  safety  and 
information system development. A fact-finding mission visited Beijing in September 2012 and 
reached  agreement  with  Integrated  Planning  Division  of  the  Comprehensive  Planning 
Department  of  the  Ministry  of  Transport  on  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation 
arrangements, cost, financing arrangement, and terms of reference for consulting services. The 
TA is in ADB’s TA program for the PRC for 2012.1 The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  After 3 decades of sustained investment, the PRC’s national trunk highway system 
(NTHS) network is now the second-longest in the world.3 Further NTHS improvements are 
envisaged as part of the PRC’s Twelfth Five-Year Plan, 2011–2015. The overall aim is to 
complete an NTHS network suitable for meeting the needs of the entire population of the PRC 
by  2020.  This  is  expected  to  be  over  100,000  kilometers  (km)  in  length.  However,  rising 
incomes have led to rapid increases in motorization and traffic levels, which have contributed to 
growing problems of congestion, road accidents, and vehicle emissions. These have become 
critical issues for NTHS management in the PRC. 
 
3.  Intelligent transport systems (ITS) have the potential to improve the efficiency and safety 
of road use and to ease traffic congestion.4 The three core elements of an ITS are detection, 
processing, and dissemination of information on traffic condition and incidents. The PRC has 
been deploying ITS on many highways, where they typically account for 1.0%–1.5% of highway 
construction cost. This has mainly relied on conventional fixed-network-based ITS, which uses 
devices  installed  at  fixed  locations.  Recent  advances  in  mobile  (wireless)  communication 
technology, combined with high levels of usage of mobile devices, now provide the platform for 
a paradigm shift from fixed-network-based ITS to mobile-network-based ITS utilizing connected 
vehicle technology including both vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V)5 and vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I)6 
approaches. Compared with a fixed-network-based ITS, connected vehicle technology provides 
an  effective  and  cost-efficient  way  of  performing  the  three  elements  of  ITS  in a  real-time 
environment by providing information individually to each driver through dedicated onboard 
equipment. It can support ITS applications for improving safety, mobility, and environmental 
performance in the following ways: 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2012. Country Partnership Strategy: People’s Republic of China, 2011–2015. Manila. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 7 September 2012. 
3  The total length of the PRC NTHS network comprised 85,000 kilometers (km) at the end of 2011. The United 
States interstate highway network has a total length of 92,000 km. 
4  ITS are advanced applications that aim to provide innovative services relating to different modes of transport and 
traffic management and enable users to be better informed and make safer, more coordinated, and “smarter” use 
of transport networks. 
5  V2V communication systems are an emerging type of networks in which vehicles act as the communicating nodes; 
providing each other with information, such as safety warnings and traffic information. As a cooperative approach, 
such systems can be more effective in avoiding accidents and traffic congestion than if each vehicle tries to solve 
these problems individually. 
6  V2I communication is the wireless exchange of critical safety and operational data between vehicles and roadway 
infrastructure, intended primarily to avoid motor vehicle crashes and congestion.

2  
(i)  Safety applications have potential to reduce crashes through providing advisory 
information and warnings. For instance, vehicle operators may be advised of a 
school zone, sharp ramp curve, or slippery patch of roadway ahead. 
(ii)  Mobility applications can create a connected, data-rich travel environment based 
on  information  transmitted  anonymously  from  thousands  of  vehicles  that  are 
using  the  transport  system  at  a  particular  time,  which  can  help  transport 
managers to monitor and manage transport system performance. 
(iii)  Environment applications can provide travelers with real-time information about 
traffic congestion and other travel conditions to help them to make more informed 
decisions that may result in their taking alternate routes or public transit. This can 
help make their trip more fuel-efficient and eco-friendly. 
 
4.  Road accidents, congestion, and vehicle emissions have become urgent problems that 
need to be addressed on the PRC’s NTHS. From 1995 to 2010, the number of deaths from 
accidents on the NTHS increased tenfold from 616 persons to 6,300 persons, growing at an 
average annual rate of 17.9%. NTHS vehicle-kilometers driven accounted for only 1.9% of 
highway vehicle-kilometer driven in 2010, but NTHS deaths made up 13.5% of highway traffic 
deaths. The average annual accident fatality rate7 for the NTHS was 27.8% during 1995–2010, 
which was 1.3 times higher than the accident fatality rate for highway traffic accidents.8 
 
5.  Road congestion has become a major issue in the PRC, especially near cities, where 
congestion levels are highest. The costs of congestion include lost time and higher transport 
costs. While detailed congestion cost studies are not yet available for the PRC, in other ADB 
developing member countries the annual cost of congestion often amounts to 2%–5% of gross 
domestic product.9 
 
6.  Tailpipe emissions from vehicles are the single largest human-made source of carbon 
dioxide (CO ), nitrous oxides, and methane. Vehicles that are stationary, idling, and traveling in 
2
a stop–go pattern due to congestion emit more than those traveling in free-flow conditions. With 
expected rapid growth in CO  emissions in the PRC and other large developing countries, global 
2
CO  emissions from transport are projected to increase nearly 50% by 2030. This will have 
2
profound  environmental,  economic,  and  social  consequences―both  in  the  PRC  and 
globally―unless the means can be introduced for containing this growth in emissions. 
 
7.  Mobile-network-based ITS offers a major opportunity for introducing new technologies 
that can augment efforts to address these problems. For the prevention of traffic accidents, this 
form of ITS can reduce the risk of crashes by providing drivers with warnings when dangerous 
situations  arise.  For  congestion  management,  the  use  of  V2I,  together  with  the  use  of 
anonymous  information  from  passengers’  wireless  devices  relayed  through  wireless 
transmission media, can dramatically improve the quality and quantity of real-time information 
on traffic conditions that is available to transport agencies, making it easier for them to manage 
transport systems for maximum efficiency and minimum congestion. V2V and V2I technologies 
can also enable travelers to avoid traffic jams by changing their route, time, and mode of travel, 
based on up-to-the-minute conditions. With reduced congestion, vehicles can operate at more 
efficient speeds that produce lower tailpipe emissions. By directly and individually receiving

8.  Mobile-network-based ITS has the potential to replace or supplement existing and future 
ITS development due to their effectiveness in terms of operation and cost, and the rapid 
proliferation of mobile-based communication infrastructure. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
9.  The TA will support highway transport information development activities within the 
government’s strategic promotion of the Internet of Things10 in the 12th Five-Year Plan. 
 
10.  It will build upon a previous ADB TA for Improving Road Safety through the Application 
of Intelligent Transport Systems,11 which examined the general ITS architecture, focusing on 
fixed-network-based ITS. The proposed TA will support the development of a policy for mobile-
communication-based ITS. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The impact will be the establishment of a mobile-communication-based ITS development 
policy  for  improving  safety,  mobility,  and  environmental  sustainability  on  the  NTHS.  The 
outcome will be a development plan for connected vehicle (V2V and V2I) technologies for ITS 
on the NTHS prepared on the basis of identified commercial and public sector perspectives and 
issues affecting connected vehicle development. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The main purpose of the TA is to provide support for establishing a policy for the 
development and implementation of a mobile-communication-based ITS, using V2V and V2I 
connected vehicle technologies. The focus will be on the use of such technologies to improve 
safety, mobility, and environmental sustainability on the NTHS. The TA will include (i) review of 
connected vehicle research and development in advanced countries and the PRC, and related 
international  standards;  (ii)  evaluation  of  commercial  and  public  sector  perspectives  of 
connected vehicle development in the PRC; (iii) review of issues affecting connected vehicle 
development in the PRC; (iv) capacity development for executing agency staff and other key 
stakeholders;  (v)  a  policy  note  on  developing  connected-vehicle-based  ITS  for  the  PRC 
highways; and (vi) policy-oriented knowledge products and services on mobile-communication-
based ITS for DMCs. 
13.  The tasks of the TA consultant will include assisting the executing agency in the design, 
execution, and evaluation of its technical testing program for the V2V and V2l technologies. The 
executing agency plans to perform this testing on a 10 km section of highway G4 of the NTHS 
located near Changsha City in Hunan Province. The section is equipped with five WiMax12 base 
stations and one China Mobile Multimedia Broadcasting station. As these communications 
infrastructure  facilities  support  V2I  and  indirect  V2V  implementation,  the  test  needs  to  be 
considered as a part of the task of identifying technological issues for developing connected 
vehicle technology in the PRC.

C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $700,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of the provision of office, utilities, telecommunications 
access,  materials,  data,  counterpart  professional  and  support  staff,  and  other  in-kind 
contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The Integrated Planning Division of the Comprehensive Planning Department of the 
Ministry of Transport will be the executing agency. The executing agency will chair a multi-
stakeholder coordination committee to support participation in the TA by other key public and 
private  agencies  with  interests  in  and  responsibilities  for  highway  management,  ITS 
technologies, road safety, and other fields relevant to the TA. The TA will be implemented from 
15 November 2012 to 30 June 2014. 
 
16.  The TA will require 7 person-months of international and 20 person-months of national 
consulting services to carry out the terms of reference (Appendix 3). Individual consultants and 
firms will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time) using the quality- and cost-based selection method with a quality–
cost ratio of 80:20.  
 
17.  The consultant will submit inception, interim, draft final, and other reports as applicable. 
The consultants will also participate in workshops to present findings and recommendations and 
to solicit feedback from key stakeholders. The workshops will be held at the inception, interim 
report and draft final report stages. ADB missions will monitor the progress and performance of 
the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Highway Safety and Information System 
Development, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

(iii)  Participate in workshops with the executing agency and stakeholders. 
(iv)  Assist the international consultant in advising the executing agency on the test 
component relating to computer technology, and compiling test results. 
(v)  Assist the international consultant in producing a policy note and knowledge 
products and services on mobile communication. 
 
9.  Road safety specialist (national, 4.0 person-months). The specialist should have at 
least 15 years of experience in road accident analysis and transport. The specialist should have 
at least a bachelor’s degree in a transport-related field. The specialist is expected to perform the 
following tasks under the supervision of the team leader and the international road safety 
specialist: 
(i)  Collect and analyze PRC highway accident and incident data to produce accident 
and incident patterns of the PRC NTHS.  
(ii)  Assist  the  international  consultant  in  producing  a  report  on  the  potential  of 
connected vehicle applications for addressing traffic accidents and incidents, and 
the potential savings. 
(iii)  Participate in workshops with the executing agency and stakeholders. 
(iv)  Produce  policy-oriented  knowledge  products  and  services  on  the  benefits  of 
connected vehicle applications in terms of safety, mobility, and environmental 
sustainability. 
(v)  Assist the international consultant in producing a policy note and knowledge 
products and services on the benefits of connected vehicle application.
